taxon_name.authority: to the Moss Genera of North America North of Mexico

bio:treatment.discussion: this key to the genera of north american mosses is intended to complement not replace the keys to genera included with each family treatment in the flora. it is a somewhat modified version of a key written earlier (d. h. vitt and w. r. buck 1992) to honor howard a. crum on his retirement from the university of michigan not replace the keys to genera included with each family treatment in the Flora. It is a somewhat modified version of a key written earlier (D. H. Vitt and W. R. Buck 1992) to honor Howard A. Crum on his retirement from the University of Michigan.
Andreaeaceae. Contributed by Richard H. Zander.

Page 104. Column 2, line 27. Distribution of Andreaea rupestris should be corrected to: Greenland; Alta., B.C., Man., N.B., Nfld. and Labr., N.W.T., N.S., Nunavut, Ont., Que., Sask., Yukon; Alaska, Ariz., Calif., Colo., Ga., Idaho, Maine, Mass., Mich., Minn., Mont., N.H., N.Y., N.C., Oreg., Tenn., Vt., Va., Wash., Wis., Wyo.; Mexico; West Indies; Central America; South America; Eurasia; Africa; Atlantic Islands; Pacific Islands; Australia; Antarctica.
Polytrichaceae. Editorial, from note by John J. Atwood.

Page 136. Column 2. Map of distribution of Polytrichum commune var. perigoniale does not have all information as given in text. The faulty map was generated automatically from the text by editorial software.
Grimmiaceae. Contributed by Roxanne I. Hastings.
Page 231. Grimmia subg. Gasterogrimmia should be Grimmia subg. Grimmia (as it includes the type of the genus, Grimmia plagiopodia).
Page 232. Column 1, line 31: change concave to keeled.
Page 232. Column 1, line 32: change keeled to concave.
Bruchiaceae. Editorial, from note by Rodney D. Seppelt.
Page 437. Genus description of Trematodon, seta dimensions should be 0.5–1.5 cm, not mm as given.

key_statement.description: Gametophytes seemingly absent (consisting only of protonemata); capsules asymmetric; setae papillose7 – 1. Buxbaumia , v. 27, p. 118
Gametophytes present (with obvious leaves); capsules and setae various.
Laminal cells arranged in a network of narrow, green cells alternating with large hyaline cells; branches usually in clusters2 – 1. Sphagnum , v. 27, p. 45
Laminal cells of one kind (green), or if two kinds, branches never in clusters.
Leaves attached in 2 rows on opposite sides of stem (distichous).
Leaves appearing split at base, consisting of 2 vaginant laminae clasping stem and base of leaf above (equitant)21 – 1. Fissidens , v. 27, p. 331
Leaves with expanded bases, not clasping leaf above.
Leaves ecostate; protonemata luminous28 – 1. Schistostega , v. 27, p. 475
Leaves with single costa; protonemata not luminous.
Vegetative leaves with smooth mucro; perichaetial leaves with smooth subula20 – 1. Bryoxiphium , v. 27, p. 329
All leaves with papillose, linear subula25 – 2. Distichium , v. 27, p. 448
Leaves attached all around stem (foliate stems sometimes flattened [complanate]).
Leaves without lamellae or filaments on adaxial costal surface (but propagula sometimes present).
Leaves deeply lobed, lobes linear-terete1 – 1. Takakia , v. 27, p. 43
Leaves never lobed, flattened (sometimes concave with margins inrolled or recurved).
Leaves ecostate, costa short and double, double or single to 1/3 leaf length, or single with 2 or 3 lateral spursSubkey A, p. 641
Leaves with single costa to at least mid leafSubkey B, p. 647
Leaves with lamellae or filaments on adaxial costal surface (excluding propagula).
Leaves with filaments on adaxial costal surface.
Leaf margins reflexed to revolute29 – 31. Crossidium , v. 27, p. 611
Leaf margins broadly inrolled (mostly obscuring filaments)29 – 32. Aloina , v. 27, p. 614
Leaves with lamellae on adaxial costal surface.
Leaves bordered with elongate marginal cells8 – 6. Atrichum (in part), v. 27, p. 147
Leaves without elongate marginal cells.
Leaves ciliate at distal part of hyaline sheath8 – 9. Bartramiopsis , v. 27, p. 161
Leaves eciliate.
Distal leaf margins 2-stratose with paired, multicellular teeth; leaf apices with slender, smooth, caducous awns8 – 8. Lyellia , v. 27, p. 159
Distal leaf margins 1-stratose with single teeth or entire; leaf apices muticous or with serrate awns.
Lamellae 2 – 4; leaves hyaline awned; plants small, less than 5 mm; peristome absent or rudimentary and fragile29 – 29. Pterygoneurum , v. 27, p. 606
Lamellae 4 – 50; leaves mostly not awned; plants mostly larger; peristome of 32 or 64 persistent teeth.
Lamellae distinctly wavy.
Distal leaf margins not bordered8 – 4. Oligotrichum (in part), v. 27, p. 142
Distal leaf margins with border of hyaline, short-rhombic cells8 – 5. Psilopilum , v. 27, p. 145
Lamellae straight.
Calyptrae naked or with few hairs.
Distal abaxial leaf lamellae and teeth absent8 – 3. Meiotrichum , v. 27, p. 141
Distal abaxial leaf lamellae and/or teeth present8 – 4. Oligotrichum (in part), v. 27, p. 142
Calyptrae densely hairy.
Capsules present.
Capsules sharply 4-angled8 – 2. Polytrichum (in part), v. 27, p. 133
Capsules cylindric or bluntly 2 – 4-angled .
Capsules with stomata; lumina of apical cells of lamellae pyriform8 – 1. Polytrichastrum (in part), v. 27, p. 124
Capsules without stomata; lumina of apical cells of lamellae not pyriform8 – 7. Pogonatum (in part), v. 27, p. 155
Capsules absent .
Apical cells of lamellae papillose.
Apical cells elliptic-pyriform8 – 1. Polytrichastrum (in part) , v. 27, p. 124
Apical cells rounded, quadrate or oblate8 – 7. Pogonatum (in part), v. 27, p. 155
Apical cells of lamellae smooth or with faint cuticular ridges.
Plants larger; leaves with or without awns8 – 2. Polytrichum (in part), v. 27, p. 133
Plants small, less than 6 mm; leaves never awned8 – 7. Pogonatum (in part), v. 27, p. 155
Leaves appearing ecostate , but with costae single and occupying entire leaf area, thus lamina appearing multistratose.
Leaves lanceolate; green cells 4-sided in transverse section24 – 1. Leucobryum (in part), v. 27, p. 441
Leaves ligulate; green cells 3-sided in transverse section33 – 1. Octoblepharum (in part), v. 27, p. 664
Leaves ecostate, costae very short and single, or double; lamina always 1-stratose.
Distal laminal cells papillose or prorulose.
Leaf apices hyaline.
Laminal cell papillae 1 or 2, forked; capsules immersed, smooth; perichaetial leaf margins ciliate; widespread38 – 1. Hedwigia , v. 28, p. 84
Laminal cell papillae 1, simple; capsules exserted, ribbed; perichaetial leaf margins entire; restricted to w North America38 – 3. Pseudobraunia , v. 28, p. 89
Leaf apices concolorous.
Laminal cells multipapillose.
Papillae arranged in rows over lumina; laminal cells more than 5:173 – 8. Taxithelium , v. 28, p. 582
Papillae randomly arranged over lumina; laminal cells less than 4:1.
Leaf apices obtuse; stems complanate-foliate27 – 1. Erpodium (in part)/27 – 2. Solmsiella , v. 27, p. 471 , 473
Leaf apices short-acuminate; stems symmetrically foliate38 – 2. Braunia , v. 28, p . 88
Laminal cells 1-papillose or prorulose.
Stems 2-or 3-pinnate, forming ascending series of flat, frondose tiers56 – 2. Hylocomium , v. 28, p. 327
Stems simple or 1-pinnate, not forming ascending series of fronds.
Leaves plicate.
Costae extending beyond mid leaf; leaves spreading to squarrose56 – 4. Rhytidiadelphus (in part), v. 28, p. 330
Costae short; leaves falcate-secund72 – 5. Ctenidium , v. 28, p. 522
Leaves not plicate.
Plants reddish black, tightly attached to rock3 – 1. Andreaea (in part), v. 27, p. 102
Plants green, on various substrates.
Plants minute, less than 2 mm, acrocarpous31 – 2. Ephemerum (in part), v. 27, p. 650
Plants large, more than 1 cm, pleurocarpous .
Costae extending to near leaf apex51 – 3. Callicostella , v. 28, p. 257
Costae ending below mid leaf .
Alar cells many, oblate to rounded, extending up margins; restricted to Pacific Northwest75 – 3. Nogopterium , v. 28, p. 595
Alar cells few, mostly quadrate, scarcely extending up margins; widespread.
Medial laminal cells less than 5:1.
Stem and branch leaves differentiated59 – 3. Heterocladium , v. 28, p. 368
Stem and branch leaves similar.
Leaves broadly ovate, strongly concave; apices obtuse to obtuse-apiculate59 – 4. Myurella , v. 28, p. 370
Leaves lanceolate to ovate-lanceolate, weakly concave or flat; apices acute to acuminate.
Leaf apices acute; margins serrulate only distally; propagula often present in leaf axils; n North America59 – 2. Pterigynandrum , v. 28, p. 367
Leaf apices acuminate; margins serrulate throughout; propagula absent; e United States64 – 2. Schwetschkeopsis , v. 28, p. 475
Medial laminal cells more than 5:1.
Basal row of laminal cells with large prorula at proximal end72 – 6. Dacryophyllum , v. 28, p. 524
Basal row of laminal cells smooth.
Apical laminal cells much shorter than medial cells72 – 18. Taxiphyllum (in part), v. 28, p. 566
Apical laminal cells scarcely differentiated.
Leaf apices acute; laminal cells prorulose only at distal ends56 – 7. Leptohymenium , v. 28, p. 336
Leaf apices slenderly acuminate; laminal cells prorulose at both ends72 – 4. Chryso-hypnum , v. 28, p. 520
Distal laminal cells smooth (rarely with minute cuticular roughenings).
Leaf apices with hyaline awn.
Laminal cells 2:1 or less, oblate-hexagonal throughout; peristome absent27 – 1. Erpodium (in part), v. 27, p. 471
Laminal cells more than 3:1, basal cells quadrate, distal cells short-rhomboidal; peristome present27 – 3. Venturiella , v. 27, p. 473
Leaf apices concolorous.
Plants aquatic, submerged at least part of year; leaves keeled or flat68 – 3. Fontinalis , v. 28, p. 494
Plants sometimes in wet habitats but never submerged; leaves never keeled.
Plants acrocarpous, usually less than 4 cm.
Plants on rock.
Plants reddish black; capsules valvate3 – 1. Andreaea (in part), v. 27, p. 102
Plants greenish brown; capsules with 4 peristome teeth5 – 2. Tetrodontium , v. 27, p. 113
Plants on bare soil.
Protonemata few; capsules globose; calyptrae very small, persistent31 – 1. Micromitrium , v. 27, p. 647
Protonemata many; capsules ovoid, apiculate; calyptrae campanulate-mitrate, deciduous31 – 2. Ephemerum (in part), v. 27, p. 650
Plants pleurocarpous, mostly larger.
Costae single, with 2 or more shorter, supplementary costae at base75 – 1. Antitrichia (in part), v. 28, p. 591
Costae double, or if single very short and without supplementary costae.
Costae double, extending to or beyond mid leaf.
Stem paraphyllia many.
Stem leaves plicate; bases decurrent56 – 1. Hylocomiastrum (in part) , v. 28, p. 326
Stem leaves not plicate; bases not decurrent56 – 3. Loeskeobryum , v. 28, p. 329
Stem paraphyllia absent.
Laminal cells thin-walled, lax, abruptly bordered by elongate cells51 – 1. Cyclodictyon , v. 28, p. 255
Laminal cells firm-walled, not or only gradually bordered.
Plants in mats; leaves falcate-secund at least at branch apices; exostome teeth striate, furrowed51 – 2. Trachyxiphium , v. 28, p. 256
Plants tufted; leaves somewhat contorted when dry but not falcate; exostome teeth papillose, not furrowed[ Lepidopilum , see 49. Hookeriaceae , v. 28, p. 248 ]
Costae single or double, usually ending just beyond leaf base.
Leaf apices obtuse; plants small, rare, restricted to mountains of se United States.
Leaves symmetric, without basal lobe72 – 1. Bryocrumia , v. 28, p. 517
Leaves asymmetric, with basal lobe77 – 4. Homaliadelphus , v. 28, p. 609
Leaf apices acute to acuminate, at least apiculate; plants mostly larger, widespread.
Laminal cells lax, hexagonal.
Lateral and dorsal leaves with similar areolation; stems irregularly branched49 – 1. Hookeria , v. 28, p. 249
Lateral and dorsal leaves differentiated in areolation; stems pinnate72 – 19. Vesicularia , v. 28, p. 570
Laminal cells firm-to thick-walled, rounded to linear.
Leaf bases slenderly long-decurrent.
Plants small to medium-sized, green; leaves not undulate; laminal cells smooth67 – 1. Plagiothecium , v. 28, p. 484
Plants large, whitish; leaves strongly undulate; laminal cells with minute, granular, cuticular papillae72 – 2. Buckiella , v. 28, p. 518
Leaf bases not at all decurrent to broadly auriculate.
Leaves dimorphic, abaxial ones symmetric, cultriform; with large area of enlarged alar cells on one side of costa63 – 3. Pilosium , v. 28, p. 472
Leaves monomorphic, symmetric; alar cells various.
Plants slender, threadlike or in thin mats; leaves mostly less than 1 mm.
Alar cells in 1 basal row, somewhat inflated, rounded73 – 3. Hageniella , v. 28, p. 575
Alar cells few, quadrate.
Branch leaves more than 0.5 mm72 – 9. Homomallium , v. 28, p. 529
Branch leaves less than 0.5 mm.
Ecostate or costae very short and double; laminal cells rhombic54 – 4. Platydictya , v. 28, p. 282
Costae short and single; laminal cells rounded-elliptic58 – 9. Pseudoleskeella (in part), v. 28, p. 361
Plants larger; leaves more than 1 mm.
Leaves falcate-secund.
Distal laminal cells oblong-rhombic, ca. 3:1.
Alar cells few, oblong-quadrate, in 1 or 2 rows along insertion73 – 2. Sematophyllum (in part), v. 28, p. 573
Alar cells many, oblate, in many rows extending up margins75 – 2. Leucodon (in part) , v. 28, p. 593
Distal laminal cells ± linear, more than 6:1.
Stems regularly and closely pinnate, featherlike, fronds flat, erect to ascending72 – 16. Ptilium , v. 28, p. 562
Stems irregularly pinnate to unbranched, not featherlike, prostrate to loosely ascending.
Mature branches erect, producing many conspicuous propagula in distal leaf axils72 – 14. Platygyrium , v. 28, p. 557
Branches not producing propagula in leaf axils.
Branches curved-secund when dry, erect when moist; alar cells small, quadrate72 – 17. Pylaisia , v. 28, p. 563
Branches little altered when dry; alar cells various.
Alar cells when differentiated quadrate, sometimes enlarged but not inflated.
Stem paraphyllia present56 – 6. Rhytidiopsis , v. 28, p. 335
Stem paraphyllia absent.
Plants very large (stem leaves 3.5 – 5 mm); stems ascending to erect; leaves plicate56 – 4. Rhytidiadelphus (in part), v. 28, p. 330
Plants smaller (stem leaves less than 3.5 mm); stems prostrate to ascending; leaf plication various.
Alar cells absent or very few; pale propagula often clustered in leaf axils72 – 11. Isopterygiopsis (in part), v. 28, p. 549
Alar cells distinctly differentiated; propagula absent, or if present, not clustered in leaf axils.
Plants on wet rock in mountain streams54 – 3. Hygrohypnum (in part), v. 28, p. 269
Plants in various habitats but not as above.
Costae to 1/3 leaf length with branches not meeting at base; Alaska, Yukon72 – 7. Gollania , v. 28, p. 525
Costae mostly shorter, branches meeting at base; widespread72 – 10. Hypnum (in part), v. 28, p. 532
Alar cells quadrate to oblong, inflated.
Plants in calcareous fens or marl pools, dark reddish brown; leaf apices obtuse61 – 2. Scorpidium (in part), v. 28, p. 387
Plants in other habitats, golden to green; leaf apices acute to acuminate.
Plants on wet rock in mountain streams54 – 3. Hygrohypnum (in part), v. 28, p. 269
Plants in various habitats but not as above.
Alar cells inflated in several rows, walls thick; leaf margins strongly serrate73 – 6. Heterophyllium , v. 28, p. 579
Alar cells inflated in 1 (or 2) rows, or if more, walls thin; leaf margins entire to serrulate.
Stems surrounded by enlarged, thin-walled, hyaline cortical cells (hyalodermis); alar regions large, subdecurrent72 – 10. Hypnum (in part), v. 28, p. 532
Stems surrounded by small, thick-walled, concolorous cells; alar regions in 1 (or 2) rows.
Plants very shiny; leaves 0.8 – 1.4 mm; distal margins densely serrulate; capsules inclined, asymmetric73 – 5. Brotherella , v. 28, p. 577
Plants slightly shiny; leaves 0.5 – 1.1 mm; distal margins distantly serrulate; capsules erect, symmetric73 – 7. Pylaisiadelpha , v. 28, p. 580
Leaves straight.
Stem leaf apices abruptly contracted to long setaceous point.
Leaf apices hyaline; alar cells scarcely differentiated59 – 1. Iwatsukiella , v. 28, p. 367
Leaf apices yellow; alar cells inflated, hyaline73 – 9. Wijkia , v. 28, p. 582
Stem leaf apices acute, acuminate or apiculate.
Leaves squarrose-recurved when dry; apices channeled.
Stem leaves greater than 2.5 mm; alar cells oblong, somewhat inflated, intramarginal56 – 4. Rhytidiadelphus (in part), v. 28, p. 330
Stem leaves less than 2.5 mm; alar cells oblong to subquadrate, inflated or not, marginal.
Leaves greater than 1.6 mm54 – 7. Campylium , v. 28, p. 287
Leaves less than 1.7 mm54 – 18. Campylophyllum , v. 28, p. 314
Leaves erect to spreading, or if squarrose only when moist; apices mostly not channeled.
Plants on wet rock in mountain streams; leaves ovate, concave54 – 3. Hygrohypnum (in part), v. 28, p. 269
Plants in various habitats but not as above; leaves various.
Stems complanate-foliate.
Alar cells many, quadrate; capsules erect69 – 1. Entodon (in part), v. 28, p. 503
Alar cells few, variously shaped; capsules usually inclined.
Plants on vertical substrates, tree trunks or rock77 – 1. Neckera (in part), v. 28, p. 603
Plants on horizontal substrates, rarely on extreme base of trees.
Leaf margins serrulate throughout.
Apical laminal cells undifferentiated72 – 8. Herzogiella (in part), v. 28, p. 527
Apical laminal cells shorter than medial cells72 – 18. Taxiphyllum (in part), v. 28, p. 566
Leaf margins entire or serrulate only distally.
Rhizoids arising from leaf axils, papillose; leaf margins ± entire72 – 11. Isopterygiopsis (in part), v. 28, p. 549
Rhizoids arising from below leaf insertion, smooth; leaf margins serrulate distally.
Pseudoparaphyllia filamentous; annuli not differentiated; sexual condition mostly monoicous72 – 12. Isopterygium (in part), v . 28, p. 552
Pseudoparaphyllia absent; annuli differentiated; sexual condition mostly dioicous72 – 15. Pseudotaxiphyllum , v. 28, p. 559
Stems symmetrically foliate.
Alar cells inflated.
Stems erect, hyalodermis present; alar cells hyaline, in auricles54 – 16. Calliergonella , v. 28, p. 312
Stems prostrate, hyalodermis absent; alar cells yellowish, not in auricles.
Alar cells uniform, without enlarged basal row; stem apices flattened72 – 3. Callicladium , v. 28, p. 519
Alar cells with enlarged basal row; stem apices not flattened.
Alar regions rounded to insertion; exostome teeth furrowed73 – 1. Acroporium , v. 28, p. 572
Alar regions not rounded to insertion; exostome teeth not furrowed.
Exostome teeth striate; endostome with evident basal membrane and segments; e North America73 – 2. Sematophyllum (in part), v. 28, p. 573
Exostome teeth smooth or faintly papillose; endostome fugacious, appearing absent; restricted to c Florida in oak scrub73 – 4. Donnellia , v. 28, p. 576
Alar cells rectangular to quadrate, not inflated.
Alar cells many (more than 50), quadrate, regions extending up margins in 12+ rows.
Stem paraphyllia many79 – 3. Alsia , v. 28, p. 627
Stem paraphyllia absent.
Leaves less than 0.8 mm; laminal cells wit h obscure cuticular roughenings58 – 3. Leptopterigynandrum , v. 28, p. 346
Leaves more than 1 mm; laminal cells smooth.
Alar cells extending up margins more than 1/3 leaf length.
Secondary stems simple or with few branches75 – 2. Leucodon (in part) , v. 28, p. 593
Secondary stems freely subpinnate79 – 1. Forsstroemia (in part), v. 28, p. 624
Alar cells extending up margins less than 1/6 leaf length.
Leaf apices mostly obtuse to acute, rarely acuminate; bases never decurrent; endostome cilia absent; widespread but not in coastal w North America69 – 1. Entodon (in part), v. 28, p. 503
Leaf apices acuminate; bases somewhat decurrent; endostome cilia present; restricted to coastal w North America, California to British Columbia78 – 3. Tripterocladium , v. 28, p. 622
Alar cells fewer (less than 25), quadrate to rectangular, regions extending up margins in less than 8 rows.
Plants epiphytic; primary stems creeping, secondary stems erect.
Secondary stems unbranched; leaves spreading with squarrose apices; propagula common76 – 1. Jaegerina (in part), v. 28, p. 598
Secondary stems irregularly branched; leaves erect; propagula absent77 – 5. Neomacounia , v. 28, p. 610
Plants terrestrial or rarely on base of trees; primary and secondary stems not differentiated.
Stem hyalodermis present; leaf margins serrulate to base72 – 8. Herzogiella (in part), v. 28, p. 527
Stem hyalodermis absent; leaf margins entire or serrulate distally.
Leaves plicate72 – 13. Orthothecium (in part), v. 28, p. 554
Leaves not plicate.
Leaf apices obtuse-apiculate.
Plants in fens; stems green, sparsely branched54 – 10. Pseudocalliergon (in part) , v. 28, p. 297
Plants widespread in acidic habitats of boreal forests; stems reddish orange, pinnate56 – 5. Pleurozium , v. 28, p. 334
Leaf apices acuminate.
Laminal cells not porose except at insertion; pseudoparaphyllia filamentous; coastal e North America inland to Midwest72 – 12. Isopterygium (in part), v. 28, p. 552
Laminal cells porose throughout; pseudoparaphyllia absent or foliose; boreal, arctic, and alpine habitats72 – 13. Orthothecium (in part), v. 28, p. 554
Stems erect, dendroid or frondose from stipe.
Leaves bordered by elongate cells.
Branch leaves dimorphic53 – 1. Hypopterygium , v. 28, p. 261
Branch leaves monomorphic .
Stems ± evenly branched, resembling small palm trees; stem leaves highly modified, triangular, hyaline or with hyaline apices; distal leaves ovate-triangular, flat46 – 3. Leucolepis , v. 28, p. 222
Stems irregularly branched; proximal stem leaves similar to distal leaves, lingulate, undulate46 – 5. Plagiomnium (in part) , v. 28, p. 229
Leaves not bordered.
Stem paraphyllia absent.
Branch leaf apical laminal cells long-hexagonal; costae slender, tapering toward apex77 – 7. Porotrichum , v. 28, p. 613
Branch leaf apical laminal cells rhombic; costae s trong, not tapering toward apex77 – 8. Thamnobryum , v. 28, p. 614
Stem paraphyllia or filamentous, paraphyllialike structures present.
Plants epiphytic; stems pinnate, frondose, curled when dry, spreading when moist74 – 3. Dendroalsia , v. 28, p. 588
Plants terrestrial (rarely on tree bases); stems dendroid, little altered when dry.
Branch leaf bases cordate to auriculate, auricles not inflated; stem paraphyllia present; stem leaf margins serrate70 – 1. Climacium (in part), v. 28, p. 509
Branch leaf bases long-decurrent, decurrencies of inflated, hyaline cells; stem lamellae present; stem leaf margins entire71 – 1. Pleuroziopsis , v. 28, p. 513
Stems prostrate to erect, simple to pinnate.
Plants blackish, tightly attached to rock in arctic and montane areas; capsules valvate.
Plants on acidic rock; capsules hygroscopic, elliptic when moist, tapering to point3 – 1. Andreaea (in part), v. 27, p. 102
Plants on calcareous rock; capsules not hygroscopic, turbinate, obtuse-conic4 – 1. Andreaeobryum , v. 27, p. 109
Plants greenish to blackish, on various substrates; capsules cleistocarpous or operculate, never valvate.
Leaves strongly squarrose-recurved; in fens35 – 4. Paludella , v. 28, p. 34
Leaves erect to squarrose; in various habitats.
Stem paraphyllia present.
Stems complanate-foliate; stem leaves undulate77 – 1. Neckera (in part), v. 28, p. 603
Stems symmetrically foliate; stem leaves not undulate.
Alar regions well differentiated, cells inflated.
Stem leaves not plicate; paraphyllia foliose, few to many54 – 1. Cratoneuron , v. 28, p. 266

Paraphyllia with cells elongate, more than 5:1, at least at apex.
Leaf margins entire to serrulate55 – 1. Elodium , v. 28, p. 321
Leaf margins strongly serrate distally.
Medial laminal cells short, oblong to quadrate, with 1 massive central papilla55 – 2. Echinophyllum , v. 28, p. 324
Medial laminal cells elongate or shortly oblong, smooth.
Distal laminal cells linear, more than 8:1; widespread56 – 1. Hylocomiastrum (in part) , v. 28, p. 326
Distal laminal cells short, 2 – 5:1; se United States70 – 1. Climacium (in part), v. 28, p. 509
Paraphyllia with cells short, 1 – 3:1.
Paraphyllia with cells papillose.
Laminal cells 1-papillose.
Stems 1-pinnate; laminal cells papillose on both surfaces60 – 1. Abietinella , v. 28, p. 374
Stems 2-or 3-pinnate; laminal cells papillose only abaxially60 – 4. Thuidium (in part), v. 28, p. 380

Costae opaque; leaf hair-points absent.
Stem and branch leaves differentiated58 – 2. Haplocladium , v. 28, p. 345
Stem and branch leaves similar.
Laminal cells elongate, oblong-rhombic to oblong-linear.
Capsules erect, symmetric; endostome segments narrow, not keeled58 – 4. Lescuraea (in part), v. 28, p. 348
